Description: Lump of red pigment, probably red ochre.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Naturally dyed clay or hydrated iron oxide, red ochre clay was used in Ancient Egypt for various purposes such as painting or make up. The pigment had to be ground and mixed with water. Another piece found, probably in the cemetery, during Gardner's season at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1888,0601.80). A small stone mortar was found in 1903 with traces of red ochre (Oxford, Ashmolean Museum AN1896-1908-E.4553), it is not certain whether this was excavated or acquired in 1903 by Hogarth.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (ZA.07)
